subject: Economics
title: The Liquidity Trap: When Interest Rates Hit Zero
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Liquidity Trap: When Interest Rates Hit Zero usable.

hook.text: Japan cut interest rates to zero in 1999. The economy didn't recover.

buildup.text: Normally, lower interest rates encourage borrowing and spending. But at zero, you can't go lower.

discovery.text: Keynes predicted this: the liquidity trap. When rates are zero, people hoard cash instead of investing.

twist.text: Paul Krugman warned in 1998 that liquidity traps were real. Mainstream economists laughed.

climax.text: The liquidity trap shows monetary policy has limits.

punchline.text: You can lead an economy to cheap money, but you can't make it borrow.

quiz.question: What is a liquidity trap?
options: Interest rates at zero fail to stimulate borrowing because people prefer holding cash
Government debt too high to borrow
